Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Studies of Nucleon Structure: Commissioning Jefferson Lab Halls A and C
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is now a well-established fact that nucleons, protons and neutrons, are made up of more elementary particles called quarks. While the theory known as Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) has become accepted as describing the strong interaction, which binds the constituent quarks and gluons in the nucleon, numerous questions still remain about the quark spatial and momentum distributions. The principle investigator and students will take a leading role in the first experiment to take place at Jefferson Lab after the recent upgrade, with the goal of measuring the quark spatial and momentum distributions in the nucleon, called the F_2 structure function. These distributions will be compared with predictions from models of the nucleon inspired by QCD theory. In addition to the scientific focus the research program will address a critical need for training of the next generation of physicists. As part of an Historically Black College or University, the graduate physics program at Hampton University broadly supports the education and training of both undergraduate and graduate students
from this under-represented group. This project will continue to provide access to advanced, internationally-competitive, scientific training for these students.

This research will study the transition from the momentum transfer region in which the quarks are asymptotically free to the region in which the quarks are bound into mesons and baryons. This will be accomplished through experiments to measure the proton magnetic form factor, GMp , and the F_2 inclusive structure function of the proton, neutron, and deuteron at large momentum transfer with significantly better precision than currently available. The project will additionally support required preparations for a later-to-run Hall B experiment to measure the F_2 structure function of the nearly free neutron in the poorly understood large x regime, and which was chosen by the Jefferson Lab Program Advisory Committee for the "High Impact" designation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This scientific research was proposed to provide critical experimental information on the fundamental structure of the protons and neutrons that make up the nucleus of atoms and are the building blocks of ordinary matter. While Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) has become accepted as the theory of the strong interaction, which binds the constituent quarks and gluons in the proton and neutron, numerous questions still remain in regards to the resulting structure of these nucleons. One of the primary tools for such studies is electromagnetic scattering experiments, where charged particles from a beam interact with the target particle to be studied. The interaction force is mediated by a virtual photon with the exchanged photon momentum effectively determining the distance scale over which the structure of the target is probed.By detecting the scattered electrons when an electron beam is incident on a target composed of like nuclei, such as protons in hydrogen or the deuteron (weakly bound proton and neutron) in deuterium.

This research focused on the transition from the high momentum transfer region in which the quarks are asymptotically free to the region in which the quarks are bound into baryons (such as the proton and neutron) and mesons. The electron’s trajectory and energy upon scattering are determined by the use of magnetic spectrometers, which transport them to a set of detectors used to determine the type of particle and its trajectory from a set of tracking detectors. The scattering angle at the target is then determined by taking the trajectory at the tracking detectors and tracing the particle backwards through the magnetic elements. Determining the correct function for this is a critical part of the spectrometer calibration. By analyzing the measured scattering probability versus the angle and energy of the scattered electron, information of the structure of the target particle can be inferred through the formalism of quantum mechanics. The structure of the nucleons is encoded in the electric (GEp) and magnetic form factor (GMp) of the proton and in the proton and deuteron F2 structure function. Measurements of these quantities at large momentum transfer to significantly better precision than was previously available was one of the intellectual merit criteria for this grant. Both experiments were successfully carried out with the data analysis on GMp completed, with a Hampton University graduate student receiving a Ph.D based on this work and a paper on the results drafted. The data analysis on the F2 is well underway and is expected to result in another Ph.D in the group within the next year.

The current program of study was accomplished via experiments utilizing the high-intensity electron beam at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (Jefferson Laboratory), which was recently upgraded to double the previous energy. The principle investigator, Dr. M. Eric Christy, and his students took a leading role in first run experiments after this upgrade and in the commissioning of beamline instrumentation and particle detectors systems for Experimental Halls A and C. This part of the project was not only critical for extracting the physics of particular interest to this project, but is also necessary to support the broader physics program at this leading facility over the next decade or more. The work on the Hall A HRS spectrometer optics and acceptance supported by this grant has already been leveraged by other experiments, with the GMp reconstruction matrix serving as the standard baseline for experiments which have run in Hall A post GMp.  The GMp collaboration, including the PI and students. has continued to provide support to these experiments.

 

Additionally, this project addressed a need for training the next generation of nuclear physicists and provided students from an under-represented group access to participation in cutting edge research at an Historically Black College or University, with minority undergraduate students contributing to this research.
